In this study, an efficient Baeyer-Villiger oxidation catalytic system based on a bicarbonate-activated hydrogen peroxide (BAP) system was developed for the efficient conversion of cyclohexanone to ε-caprolactone using a MgO-SnO2 composite metal oxide catalyst. Characterization techniques, including XRD, FT-IR, SEM, BET, and XPS, provide insights into the changes in the chemical states and the influence of the morphology and structure of Mg and Sn within the catalyst and their impact on reaction performance. The catalytic performance of MgO-SnO2 in the BAP system outperforms MgO and Mg(OH)2 catalysts in the H2O2/acetonitrile/cyclohexanone system, with a notable increase in yield. A comprehensive mechanistic framework elucidating the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation pathway within the BAP system was developed employing density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, enabling the generation of a highly reactive methylperoxenamine anion via catalytic activation of H2O2. Comprehensive XPS characterization revealed that Lewis acid sites located on the SnO2 surface induced polarization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl group, thereby facilitating a marked enhancement in Criegee intermediate formation efficiency through optimized electrophilic activation pathways. In addition, the BAP system offers the advantage of reducing the loss of active components and effectively promoting the formation of reactive intermediates, thereby significantly enhancing lactone yield and catalyst reusability. This study provides new insights into the application of oxide catalysts in the Baeyer-Villiger reaction and offers a theoretical foundation for the future optimization of catalysts. Graphical abstract MgO-SnO2 catalysts synthesized by the co-precipitation method catalyzed the BV oxidation of cyclohexanone to produce ε-caprolactone in the BAP system and elucidated the reaction mechanism by DFT theoretical calculations. Keywords Baeyer-Villiger oxidation MgO-SnO2 BAP system H2O2 Acetonitrile Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polycaprolactone (PCL), as a polymer material with excellent biocompatibility and controlled degradation properties, PCL finds significant applications in biomedical fields [1–3], coatings [4], composites [5,6], and agriculture [7]. The synthesis of its precursor monomer, ε-caprolactone, has consequently garnered substantial research interest. Among contemporary synthetic strategies, the Baeyer-Villiger (BV) oxidation of cyclohexanone has emerged as the predominant industrial production methodology for ε-caprolactone, owing to its well-established process parameters and superior product selectivity. The current industrial BV oxidation process can be divided into two categories: one is the Mukaiyama method [8], which introduces O2 and aldehyde sacrificial agents (such as benzaldehyde) to generate peracid oxidants in situ. Although this method has advantages such as environmental friendliness and high safety, the traditional thermal catalytic process relies on metal catalysts and must be carried out at high temperatures, resulting in high energy consumption and the risk of metal residue [9,10]. Another method is direct oxidation using peroxyacids/hydrogen peroxide. Despite the high conversion obtained with these reagents, the byproducts produced during the reaction, particularly the carboxylic acids, are highly corrosive, which not only reduces selectivity but also induces a considerable environmental hazard due to their caustic properties. Moreover, the synthesis of peroxyacids is both costly and hazardous. Conversely, H2O2 emerges as a viable alternative. As an environmentally friendly oxidant, it produces only water as a byproduct and is both inexpensive and easily disposable. In recent years, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) has attracted widespread attention in the field of biological oxidation. It is environmentally friendly, efficient, and highly selective in catalytic reactions, making it particularly suitable for use in green chemical synthesis processes [11–14]. However, the relatively moderate oxidizing power of H2O2 necessitates the use of catalysts to enhance reaction efficiency, underscoring the crucial role of catalyst development in these systems. Recent advances in heterogeneous catalysis have highlighted the growing prominence of tin-, iron-, copper-, and magnesium-based systems for the BV oxidation reaction. Corma et al. [15] first demonstrated that tin-containing β-zeolites were effective catalysts in BV oxidation. The Lewis acid center of framework-incorporated Sn (IV) sites activates ketonic carbonyls and promotes the nucleophilic attack of H2O2 on the carbonyl carbon, resulting in a selectivity of more than 95% for the BV oxidation reaction of unsaturated ketones. Liu et al. [16] synthesized hierarchical tin-β-zeolites with abundant mesoporous structures by hydrothermal synthesis, which enhanced the molecular diffusivity of the organic molecules and the accessibility of the active sites. Chen et al. [10] employed in situ Raman spectroscopy to demonstrate that SnO2 activates cyclohexanone through coordinating with the oxygen atom of its carbonyl group. Collectively, these studies demonstrate that SnO2 incorporation enhances the BV oxidation efficiency of ketones. However, the standalone SnO2 exhibits limited activity, motivating the rational design of composite metal oxide catalysts as a superior strategy. Another widely utilized system involves solid base catalysts, as evidenced by the work of Ruiz et al. and Li et al. [12–14], who prepared composite metal oxide catalysts including MgO, Mg(OH)2, Mg/Al, Mg/Sn and Mg/Al/Sn, which have exhibited significant catalytic activity in the BV oxidation and proposed a rational reaction mechanism. Notably, the highest yield of ε-caprolactone was observed when benzonitrile was employed as a solvent [10]. This is mainly because it can increase the contact area between the organic phase and the aqueous phase, promote the migration of reactants, and its molecular structure is conducive to the formation of effective reaction intermediates. Acetonitrile, on the other hand, has a lower reaction efficiency due to the presence of acid protons [17]. However, benzylnitrile is more costly and toxic compared to acetonitrile. Consequently, acetonitrile is mainly used as a solvent in this study, aligning with the principle of green chemistry. Furthermore, MgO, a simple and economical solid base catalyst, aids in the nucleophilic attack by H2O2 at the Bronsted basic sites on the catalyst surface, leading to the formation of peroxidic species. Therefore, we used MgO-SnO2 as a catalyst to catalyze the BV oxidation reaction of cyclohexanone. However, H2O2 solutions are acidic, which leads to significant leaching of magnesium from the active ingredient. This phenomenon has resulted in partial catalyst deactivation [18].In contrast, increasing the strength of alkalinity to reduce magnesium leaching accelerates the breakdown of H2O2. Therefore, there is an urgent need to identify an effective strategy that can reduce magnesium leaching while minimizing excess H2O2 consumption. The strategy must be designed to protect the active ingredient and improve the utilization efficiency of H2O2. The BAP system is generated from H2O2 and bicarbonate via hydration of CO2, producing HCO4 - oxidant species in an equilibrium reaction. In this system, HCO4 - acts as an oxidizing species. The mechanism and kinetic modeling of HCO4 - formation were proposed by Richardson et al. [19]. First, CO2 is formed by dehydration of H2CO3 and then reacts with H2O2, which then reacts with the conjugate base HO2 - to form HCO4 - as shown in Eqs. (1)-(4). The BAP system is widely used in a variety of organic reactions because of its efficient oxidizing ability. The BAP system demonstrates notable efficacy in methionine oxidation [20]. When applying this system to α₁-antitrypsin, the secondary rate constant of HCO4 - shows parity with unbound methionine residues, indicating that direct methionine oxidation occurs via peroxocarbonate mediation. The BAP system exhibits a broad substrate scope in olefin epoxidation, effectively transforming terminal alkenes (e.g., 1-octene) and stereochemical challenging substrates like cyclooctene [21]. HCO4 - epoxidizes olefins via a concerted oxygen-transfer mechanism, which suppresses the generation of large amounts of diols, is suitable for homogeneous reactions in water or mixed water/solvent solutions, and demonstrates that HCO4 - is an effective oxidant in aqueous solutions. In addition, Peng et al. [22] and Robert Karcz et al. [23] employed layered double hydroxide (LDH) as a catalyst to increase the yield of ε-caprolactone in the BAP system, but failed to elucidate the reaction pathway of BV oxidation of cyclohexanone to generate ε-caprolactone catalyzed in the BAP system. (1) HCO3 - + H+ → H2CO3 (2) H2CO3 → CO2(aq) + H2O (3) H2O2 + OH- → OOH- + H2O (4) CO2(aq) + OOH- → HCO4 - In this study, to construct an efficient BV oxidation reaction system, the BAP system was introduced using MgO-SnO2 as the catalyst. This system enables efficient cyclohexanone conversion via multiphase catalysis by synergistically combining H2O2 and HCO4 -. In this study, we comprehensively investigated the structural features, morphology, and surface chemistry of the catalysts using multiple characterization techniques, with a particular focus on the formation of surface oxygen vacancies and active sites. Building on these findings, we further explored the BV oxidation of cyclohexanone for caprolactone synthesis within the BAP system by integrating experimental studies with theoretical calculations, thereby elucidating the reaction's catalytic mechani sm. This study aims to propose novel strategies and establish theoretical bases for designing and optimizing BV oxidation catalytic systems, thereby advancing research in related fields. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis methods 2.1.1 Preparation of MgO-SnO2-α catalysts Using MgO-SnO2 with a Mg/Sn molar ratio of 3:1 as an example, 0.12mol (30.77g) of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.04mol (14.02g) of SnCl4·5H2O were dissolved in 20mL of deionized water and stirred at 35°C for 30minutes until the solution became completely transparent. A 5wt% Na2CO3 solution was then prepared and slowly added to the above solution until precipitation ceased. Subsequently, a 2.5% ammonia solution was added dropwise to adjust the pH to 10. The mixture was stirred for an additional 2hours and then allowed to stand at room temperature for 36hours. The resulting suspension was filtered through a Büchner funnel and washed with deionized water until the filtrate was free of Cl- ions. The filter cake was dried overnight at 100°C, subsequently ground, and calcined in a muffle furnace at a heating rate of 5°C per minute until it reached 600°C, where it was maintained for 2hours. The final catalyst was designated MgO-SnO2-3. By altering the Mg/Sn molar ratio to 4:1, 3:1, 2:1, and 1:1, various MgO-SnO2-α catalysts (where "α" represents the molar ratio of the magnesium salt) were synthesized. MgO and SnO2 are synthesized by the same method, and Mg(OH)2 is formed from MgO during the preparation process without calcination. Under the BAP system, MgO, Mg(OH)2, and SnO2 are named MgO BAP, Mg(OH)2 BAP, and SnO2 BAP, respectively. 2.1.2 Catalyst regeneration After centrifugation, the solid catalyst was washed several times with acetonitrile and dried at 100°C. The recovered catalyst was labeled as MgO-SnO2-αSβ, and the catalyst recovered under the BAP system was labeled as MgO-SnO2-αBβ. For example, the first recovery of a catalyst with a molar ratio of Mg: Sn of 2 in a conventional system is named MgO-SnO2-2S1, and in a BAP system, it is named MgO-SnO2-2B1. 2.2 Characterization Techniques X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected using a Dutch Aeris Research X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154nm) in the 20° to 45° range at a scan rate of 6°/min. We employed DFT with the def2-TZVP [25] basis set and simulated the solvent environment using water in the IEF-PCM solvation model. In STEP 1, we performed geometry optimization and vibrational frequency calculations for the reactants (peroxymonocarbonate R1 and acetonitrile R2) using the ωB97X-D functional [26]. Subsequent potential energy surface (PES) scanning of O (1)-C (3) in steps of 0.025Å was performed to obtain the geometrically structured mutation points on the PES. We performed geometry optimization of the transition state (TS) and vibrational frequency calculations for this structure to confirm the TS for STEP 1 of the reaction. The frequency calculations yielded only one imaginary frequency, and the vibrational mode direction aligned with the reaction coordinate, as expected. We validated the transition state structure of STEP 1 by simulating the reaction path using intrinsic reaction coordinates (IRC) [27]. Additionally, we performed geometry optimization and vibrational frequency calculations on the IRC-predicted products to determine the thermodynamic parameters of the reactants, transition states, and products in STEP 1. It is noteworthy that there are two geometrical structure mutation points in the potential energy surface scanning of C (5)-O (6), and the results of transition state geometry optimization and frequency calculations indicate the existence of multiple transition state structures for STEP 2. 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Morphology and Structures of Catalysts The crystal structures of MgO-SnO2-α and SnO2 were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques. In Fig. 1a, 2θ = 33.7° and 51.5° correspond to the (101) and (211) planes of the tetragonal rutile structure of SnO2 (PDF#41-1445) [28]. However, no diffraction peaks for MgO were observed, indicating that MgO may exist in an amorphous state in the catalyst or that its high dispersibility may be responsible for this phenomenon [29,30]. As the Mg content increased, the intensity of the SnO2 peaks decreased, and the full width at half maximum (FWHM) increased. This is likely due to the substitution of Sn4+ ions (with an ionic radius of 0.69Å) by smaller Mg2+ ions (with an ionic radius of 0.66Å) in the SnO2 lattice. This state leads to the formation of a solid solution, disrupting the original lattice structure of MgO, which results in the disappearance of MgO’s diffraction peaks and a decrease in the crystallinity of SnO2 [29,31]. The average crystallite size of SnO2 in MgO-SnO2-α was estimated using the Debye-Scherrer equation [32] based on the most prominent (101) and (211) planes. The results of the calculations are provided in Table S1. An increase in Mg content has been shown to change the crystallite size of SnO2. This phenomenon can be attributed to the segregation of MgO onto the surface of SnO2 nanoparticles [33]. Upon introduction of MgO, it has been observed that it nucleates as a secondary phase and migrates to the surface of SnO2 [34], forming a coating layer that suppresses the growth of SnO2 crystals. This process leads to a reduction in the crystallite size of SnO2. The BET surface area of MgO-SnO2-α catalysts was assessed through N2 adsorption/desorption measurements, presented in Fig. S1. According to the IUPAC classification, all four MgO-SnO2-α catalysts exhibit type IV isotherms, indicating their mesoporous nature. Two distinct hysteresis loops are observed at relative pressures (P/P0) of 0.48-0.66 and 0.85-1.0: the former corresponds to a smaller loop, characteristic of an H3-type hysteresis, which, in combination with SEM characterization results (Fig.3), suggests the presence of a small number of accumulated pores in the catalysts. This phenomenon may arise from partial sintering of the nanospheres during the calcination process. The latter corresponds to an H1-type hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of a large number of continuous channels in the MgO-SnO2-α catalysts. Pore size distribution (Fig. S2) reveals that mesopores in MgO-SnO2-α are mainly centered around 4.7nm and 32.8nm. The smaller mesopores are attributed to the free aggregation of nanoparticles. Notably, MgO-SnO2-3 shows a more concentrated pore size distribution, whereas MgO-SnO2-2 exhibits greater uniformity. The adsorption-desorption isotherms indicate that MgO-SnO2-2 has a smaller hysteresis loop, implying improved reactant adsorption and desorption behavior. Larger mesopores are mainly associated with voids between microspheres. As summarized in Table 1, MgO-SnO2-2 demonstrates a specific surface area of 118m²/g—significantly higher than the typical value of around 70 m2/g for pure MgO [35]. This enhancement is attributed to the incorporation of SnO2, which not only moderates the catalyst’s alkalinity but also increases the surface area, thereby exposing more active sites. The relatively small pore size of MgO-SnO2-2 promotes efficient contact between reactants and active sites while limiting the diffusion of larger molecules, improving selectivity and favoring the formation of target products. The moderate specific surface area contributes notably to its high catalytic performance. The morphological characteristics of MgO-SnO2-α were meticulously examined using SEM (In Fig. 2a-d). All samples were characterized by microspheres with an average particle size of approximately 110nm, which aggregated in an unordered manner, with smaller nanoparticles covering the microsphere surfaces. Specifically, MgO-SnO2-1 microspheres were found to be relatively dispersed, with nanoparticles distributed randomly on the surface; MgO-SnO2-2 microspheres were more uniform, with tightly bound particles and evenly distributed nanoparticles, whereas MgO-SnO2-3 and MgO-SnO2-4 exhibited significant nanoparticle agglomeration, forming larger microspheres. The results of the BET analysis suggest that an increase in Mg content leads to a transition in the microspheres from a dispersed to an aggregated state, accompanied by a decrease in surface area and pore size. Further increases in Mg content appear to intensify the agglomeration process, potentially resulting in alterations to the pore structure, such as pore collapse or merging, which in turn leads to the formation of larger pores. Furthermore, TEM was utilized to observe the distribution of nanospheres in MgO-SnO2-2, as illustrated in Fig. 2e-k. This phenomenon is also responsible for the absence of any peaks other than SnO2 in the XRD results. Further confirmation of the high dispersion of Mg, Sn, and O elements in the catalyst is provided by elemental mapping (Fig. 2i-k). In summary, the moderate specific surface area facilitates the increase of active sites on the catalyst surface, thereby promoting the accumulation of reactants on the surface and accelerating the reaction process. Additionally, the well-organized pore structure facilitates the diffusion of reactant molecules within the catalyst, thus further enhancing its catalytic efficiency. These catalysts' surface compositions and chemical states were examined using XPS to elucidate the structure-activity relationship. The Mg 1s spectra ( Fig. 3a) can be decomposed into two distinct peaks at 1305.8eV and 1304.5eV, which are associated with Mg-O and Mg-OH [36], respectively. Fig. 3c provides a more detailed analysis of the O 1s spectrum, which can be decomposed into three peaks: 530.04eV related to lattice oxygen, 531.45eV related to oxygen vacancies (Oads), and 532.35eV related to oxygen in adsorbed chemicals (Og) [38]. In metal oxides, M-O-M bonds typically form in three-dimensional lattice structures, and the insertion of different M0 units (where M0 represents elements with different electronegativities) leads to the formation of different M-O-M0 bonds and a redistribution of charge density. AAS analysis showed that MgO-SnO2-2S leached more Mg than MgO-SnO2-2BAP. It can be concluded that MgO-SnO2-2BAP has a higher relative Mg content, and the extent of substitution of Sn4+-O-Sn4+ bonds by Sn4+-O-Mg2+ bonds is greater in MgO-SnO2-2BAP than in MgO-SnO2-2S. Considering that the electronegativity of Sn4+ (1.73) is higher than that of Mg2+ (1.34), the substitution of Sn4+-O by Mg2+-O may increase the electron density of Sn orbitals, resulting in a chemical shift in the Sn 3d spectra of the two samples. Meanwhile, the Sn 3d spectra peak deconvolution revealed a higher Sn2+/Sn4+ molar ratio in MgO-SnO2-2BAP (0.31) compared to MgO-SnO2-2s (0.26), suggesting enhanced Lewis acid site density in MgO-SnO2-2BAP [40]. This phenomenon can be attributed to the heterolytic decomposition of H2O2 during catalysis, which generates superoxide anions (HO2 -). These anions selectively coordinate with Sn4+ centers on the SnO2 surface, forming a Sn4+-O-O transition-state complex. Subsequently, heterolytic cleavage of the O-O bond occurs, followed by O2(g) desorption. In contrast, in the BAP system, HCO4 - acts as an additional source of HO2 - (confirmed by density functional theory calculations; mechanism discussion in Section 3.3), which synergistically enhances the aforementioned reduction process. Therefore, the BAP system may promote the formation of additional oxygen vacancies, thereby generating a higher density of Lewis acid sites. Compared to the non-BAP system, the increased acid site density in the BAP system significantly enhances the activation of cyclohexanone carbonyl groups and substantially accelerates the BV oxidation reaction process. These results suggest that the framework structure of the catalyst remains intact before and after the reaction. 3.2 Catalytic performance of catalysts Initially, we conducted a comparative study of the catalytic performance of MgO-SnO2, MgO, Mg(OH)2, and SnO2 under BAP and non-BAP systems, as shown in the Table. 2. We found that under the same conditions, MgO-SnO2-2 exhibited the best catalytic performance. This is because MgO and Mg(OH)2 are more prone to chemical reactions with H2O2, leading to the gradual dissolution of the MgO and Mg(OH)2 catalysts during the reaction process, thereby significantly reducing catalyst lifespan. Additionally, MgO and Mg(OH)2 have higher alkalinity than MgO-SnO2-2, making them more prone to hydrolyzing ε-caprolactone, resulting in a significant decrease in selectivity. On the other hand, SnO2 as a catalyst exhibits the weakest catalytic activity but the highest selectivity. This is because SnO2, as a typical Lewis acid catalyst, has surface alkalinity that is far lower than that of magnesium-based catalysts. Its activity depends on the exposure of tin ions (Sn4⁺) on the surface to Lewis acid sites, which effectively promotes the activation of the ketone carbonyl group of cyclohexanone. However, its ability to activate H2O2 is weak, resulting in a lower conversion rate. As a result, compared to magnesium-based catalysts, it reduces the consumption of hydrogen peroxide and minimizes the hydrolysis of ε-caprolactone. The MgO-SnO2-2 catalyst exhibits superior catalytic performance compared to single-component catalysts, effectively balancing the activation of both H2O2 and cyclohexanone. The underlying mechanism involves the reaction of NaHCO3 with H2O2 to form peroxymonocarbonate (HCO4 -), which elevates the system pH and thereby effectively inhibits the dissolution of Mg2+. Given the pivotal role of acetonitrile in the entire reaction system, we systematically explored the catalytic effects under blank conditions as well as in various alternative solvents, including methanol and 1,4-dioxane, within both the BAP (base-assisted peroxide) system and the conventional system, as shown in Table S3. Our findings revealed that, irrespective of whether the reaction was conducted in the BAP system or the conventional system, cyclohexanone could only be effectively oxidized to ε-caprolactone in the presence of acetonitrile. This is because acetonitrile, as a non-protonic solvent, cannot provide H+, thereby better protecting the HOO- group activated by the MgO-SnO2 catalyst, making it easier for the HOO- group to directly attack the activated ketone carbonyl group. However, methanol, as a strong protonic solvent, clearly blocks the HOO-group from attacking the ketone carbonyl group. 1,4-Dioxane, as a weakly polar solvent, is unfavorable for H2O2 deprotonation, thereby inhibiting the generation of HOO⁻. Additionally, the lone pair of electrons on its oxygen atom may adsorb onto the active sites on the catalyst surface, reducing the catalyst's activity. Our STEP 1 calculations reveal that the oxidation of acetonitrile by peroxymonocarbonate in the BV system proceeds via a carbon-positive ions nucleophilic addition mechanism. In polar solvents, peroxymonocarbonate decomposes to generate a strongly oxidizing superoxide anion (HO2 -), which reacts with the CN triple bond in acetonitrile, forming an acetonitrile-superoxide transition-state complex. This promotes O (6)-directed nucleophilic attack on the cyclohexanone carbonyl carbon. TS 1, identified as the second stationary point via transition state optimization, corresponds to a first-order saddle point on the potential energy surface. The imaginary frequency mode of TS 1 indicates vibrational motion along the O (6)→C (5) attack direction, leading to the formation of the methylperoxyamine-cyclohexanone complex (M 1). By integrating catalytic performance analysis, characterization data, and DFT simulations, we propose a mechanism for the MgO-SnO2 catalyzed BV oxidation reactions of cyclohexanone in the BAP system ( Fig. 9). In this system, bicarbonate activates H2O2 to generate HCO4 -, which synergizes with H2O2 to drive the BV oxidation through dual oxidative pathways. Specifically, HCO4 - acts as the oxidant agent with acetonitrile to form methylperoxyamine anion, while H2O2 is not only co-activated on the MgO-SnO2 surface but also synergizes with HCO4 - to drive methylperoxyamine anion formation through cooperative peroxidation: (1) H2O2 interacts with Brønsted basic sites on MgO-SnO2 to form metal hydroperoxides (MOOH, M = Mg/Sn) [17,48,49] , which react with acetonitrile to yield methylperoxyamine anion; (2) simultaneously, the carbonyl group of cyclohexanone coordinates to Lewis acid sites (Sn4+/Mg2+) in MgO-SnO2, polarizing the C=O bond and enhancing the electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon. This coactivation by Brønsted and Lewis sites enables methylperoxyamine anion to attack the activated carbonyl carbon, forming a Criegee-type intermediate that rearranges to ε-caprolactone. The mechanism highlights the critical synergy between HCO4 - and H2O2 in the BAP system, coupled with the bifunctional role of MgO-SnO2 in simultaneously activating peroxides and substrates. 4 Conclusion In this work, we developed an efficient MgO-SnO2-catalyzed system for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone to ε-caprolactone within the BAP system. The catalytic system exhibits superior catalytic performance compared to the traditional H2O2/acetonitrile/cyclohexanone/MgO-SnO2-2 system, with a significant increase in lactone yield. In addition, the BAP system improves the cycle efficiency of the catalyst by reducing the loss of active components and promoting the formation of active intermediates. This study pioneers the application of DFT to simulate the complete BV oxidation pathway in the BAP system, which clarified the intermediate evolution pathways and transition state configurations of the key steps, such as the generation of the anion of methylperoxoenamine and the rearrangement of the Criegee intermediates as well as revealed the molecular mechanism of the reaction kinetics modulation of the SnO2 component through polarized C=O at the level of the electronic structure. Notably, DFT calculations and XPS analysis indicate that the generated HO2- enhances Sn2+ mediated oxygen vacancy formation and amplifies the carbonyl polarization effect in the BAP system. Secondly, H2O2 is not only synergistically activated on the MgO-SnO₂ surface but also interacts synergistically with HCO4⁻, driving the formation of methyl peroxyamine anions through synergistic peroxidation, thereby accelerating the formation of Criegee intermediates. Furthermore, the study also highlights the stability of the MgO-SnO2-2 catalyst during the reaction process, particularly its catalytic performance in the BAP system compared to MgO and SnO2 catalysts. Characterization results indicate that the chemical state of Sn plays a pivotal role in determining the catalytic performance. XRD, FT-IR, and XPS analyses confirm the stability of the catalyst framework and the changes in its chemical state during the catalytic process. The results of this study provide a novel theoretical basis for the application of oxide catalysts in the Baeyer-Villiger reaction and demonstrate the advantages of the BAP system in improving reaction efficiency, reducing catalyst deactivation, and promoting catalyst stability. Subsequent research will focus on optimizing catalyst design and exploring its application potential under various reaction conditions, with the ultimate goal of developing a highly efficient catalytic system that better meets industrial application needs. coredata.dc:description: In this study, an efficient Baeyer-Villiger oxidation catalytic system based on a bicarbonate-activated hydrogen peroxide (BAP) system was developed for the efficient conversion of cyclohexanone to ε-caprolactone using a MgO-SnO2 composite metal oxide catalyst. Characterization techniques, including XRD, FT-IR, SEM, BET, and XPS, provide insights into the changes in the chemical states and the influence of the morphology and structure of Mg and Sn within the catalyst and their impact on reaction performance. The catalytic performance of MgO-SnO2 in the BAP system outperforms MgO and Mg(OH)2 catalysts in the H2O2/acetonitrile/cyclohexanone system, with a notable increase in yield. A comprehensive mechanistic framework elucidating the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation pathway within the BAP system was developed employing density-functional theory (DFT) calculations, enabling the generation of a highly reactive methylperoxenamine anion via catalytic activation of H2O2. Comprehensive XPS characterization revealed that Lewis acid sites located on the SnO2 surface induced polarization of the cyclohexanone carbonyl group, thereby facilitating a marked enhancement in Criegee intermediate formation efficiency through optimized electrophilic activation pathways. In addition, the BAP system offers the advantage of reducing the loss of active components and effectively promoting the formation of reactive intermediates, thereby significantly enhancing lactone yield and catalyst reusability. This study provides new insights into the application of oxide catalysts in the Baeyer-Villiger reaction and offers a theoretical foundation for the future optimization of catalysts.
